content:
Diagnosis
	1. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (undifferentiated, EBV positive)
	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	Not indicated

	Radiotherapy
	15 Jan - 20 Feb 2024: Radical chemoradiotherapy to nasopharynx and neck (70Gy in 35#)

	Chemotherapy
	1. Concurrent cisplatin 100mg/m2 q3weekly with radiotherapy (2 cycles completed, 3rd omitted due to deteriorating renal function)
	2. Palliative carboplatin/gemcitabine commenced March 2024

	Clinical studies
	None

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with new pulmonary metastases and increasing bone metastases

	Current issues
	1. Worsening bone pain
	2. Progressive dyspnoea
	3. Deteriorating renal function

	Summary of consultation

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with his wife. Unfortunately, his recent CT scan from 15/4/24 shows clear evidence of disease progression with new pulmonary metastases and increasing size and number of bone metastases, particularly affecting T4-T6 vertebrae and left acetabulum. This correlates with his worsening symptoms of bone pain and increasing breathlessness.

He has completed two cycles of carboplatin/gemcitabine but with limited tolerance - grade 3 thrombocytopenia requiring two platelet transfusions and one episode of neutropenic sepsis requiring hospital admission. His renal function has deteriorated with eGFR now 38 (baseline 65).

Performance status has declined to ECOG 2-3, spending approximately 50% of the day resting. He requires regular breakthrough oxycodone for bone pain despite being on MST 60mg BD. His wife reports he is sleeping poorly due to pain.

Given the clear evidence of disease progression and poor tolerance of current chemotherapy, we have had a detailed discussion about changing approach. His PDL1 status (CPS 35) supports use of immunotherapy. We have agreed to commence pembrolizumab monotherapy with concurrent denosumab for bone metastases.

	Further investigations
	Urgent MRI spine to assess for cord compression
	Baseline thyroid function and cortisol prior to immunotherapy

	Medication prescribed
	Pembrolizumab 200mg q3weekly
	Denosumab 120mg q4weekly
	Increased MST to 90mg BD

	Follow up
	Next oncology review in 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 pembrolizumab
	Urgent palliative care referral made

	Required GP actions
	Weekly monitoring of renal function
	Please prescribe laxatives for opiate-induced constipation

primary_cancer.metastases: pulmonary metastases and bone metastases affecting T4-T6 vertebrae and left acetabulum

cancer_timeline.value: Radical chemoradiotherapy to nasopharynx and neck (70Gy in 35#)
Third cycle cisplatin omitted due to deteriorating renal function
Grade 3 thrombocytopenia requiring platelet transfusions and episode of neutropenic sepsis
CT shows new pulmonary metastases and increasing bone metastases
Stopping carboplatin/gemcitabine due to disease progression and poor tolerance

patient_facts.value: ECOG 2-3, spending approximately 50% of the day resting
Worsening bone pain requiring regular breakthrough oxycodone despite MST 60mg BD
Deteriorating renal function with eGFR now 38 (baseline 65)

status_updates.value: Stage IVB nasopharyngeal carcinoma with progressive pulmonary and bone metastases following chemoradiotherapy and palliative chemotherapy. Poor tolerance of current treatment with declining performance status.
Progressive disease on carboplatin/gemcitabine with new pulmonary metastases and increasing bone metastases
Grade 3 thrombocytopenia requiring platelet transfusions and neutropenic sepsis
Changing from carboplatin/gemcitabine to pembrolizumab monotherapy with denosumab for bone metastases
Deterioration in performance status to ECOG 2-3 with increasing pain and dyspnoea
Urgent MRI spine to assess for cord compression, baseline thyroid function and cortisol
Oncology review in 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 pembrolizumab, urgent palliative care referral made
